awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF Continuous vs. mixed-mode deformation during construction of the southern central Andes: Investigating the spatiotemporal scales of Cordilleran tectonic regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Chelsea Mackaman-Lofland has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct research, professional development, and educational activities at the University of Connecticut (UConn) under the mentorship of Professors Julie Fosdick and Michael Hren. This project investigates the spatial and temporal scales of crustal deformation during construction of the southern central Andes (~30°S) in South America. Project results will improve scientific understanding of the forces and geodynamic mechanisms driving subduction-related mountain building. The Andes define key examples of mountain building during the subduction of oceanic crust beneath a continental plate, and are integral to Earth systems including ocean/atmospheric circulation patterns, biological diversity, and natural hazard and resource distribution. At ~30°S, contrasting models of Andean mountain building invoke continuous crustal shortening vs. episodic shortening, extensional, and possibly neutral conditions in the overriding plate. This project integrates structural mapping, basin analysis, geo/thermochronology, and paleoaltimetry of bedrock and hinterland basin fill at ~30°S to (1) resolve conflicting shortening, extensional, and/or neutral deformation mode interpretations and (2) quantify the timing, magnitude, and rates of deformation, crustal evolution, surface uplift, and establishment of the Andean Cordillera. Research and professional development will involve geological field training for Argentine undergraduate students and training for an undergraduate thesis project at the host institution. The UConn undergraduate will be recruited through the newly funded GEOPAths internship and career-mentoring program, which emphasizes the recruitment and retention of underrepresented student groups. Project results will be incorporated into a field trip for Argentine and Chilean students and activities for the “Mountains, Rivers, and Carbon” and “Paleogeography, Tectonics, and Global Climate” educational outreach programs at UConn.
 
Subduction-related mountain building has long been attributed to continuous shortening and thickening of the overriding plate following margin-scale changes in plate convergence. However, an increasing body of structural, stratigraphic, and magmatic evidence points to episodic deformation, with potentially regional shortening, extension, and/or neutral regimes during the construction of Cordilleran orogens. Along the transition from central to southern Andes (~25−35°S), upper-plate deformation involved an apparent shift from continuous shortening to mixed-mode deformation. Characterizing the nature of this transition is fundamental to understanding the timing, tempo, and spatial continuity of convergent margin processes, but existing reconstructions invoke conflicting tectonic conditions most apparent along a single orogenic transect at ~30°S. This research seeks to resolve conflicting deformation mode interpretations and provide geographic and timing parameters with which to interrogate potential regional or plate-scale mechanisms controlling Cordilleran deformation. Combined zircon Lu-Hf (Lutetium-Hafnium) and U-Pb (Uranium-Lead) geochronology, low-temperature thermochronology, and stable isotope paleoaltimetry analyses will establish quantitative relationships between deformation, exhumation, crustal thickening, and surface uplift. Reconstruction of precursor deformation and sedimentation history will provide a framework with which to investigate the influence of inherited tectonic regimes and basin architectures on Neogene growth of the modern Andes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to quantify the spatial and temporal scales of shortening, neutral, and/or extensional deformation modes during construction of the southern central Andes to (i) resolve seemingly incompatible interpretations of tectonic regimes along the study transect at ~30 to 33 degrees south and (ii) provide geographic and timing parameters with which to interrogate the mechanisms controlling orogenesis in Cordilleran tectonic settings. Significant outcomes are as follows:

Detrital zircon U-Pb results of Mesozoic-Cenozoic nonmarine deposits exposed in the Andean hinterland at ~30 to 33 degrees south yield maximum depositional ages (MDAs) that considerably refine hinterland chronostratigraphy and enable discrimination of potential sediment source regions based on age signatures. δD measurements from lipid biomarkers and hydrated volcanic glass reveal the relative effects of climate and tectonics on isotopic signatures preserved in long-lived, high-elevation basins. Our samples span 45 to 7.8 Ma, with δD values (corrected for precipitation, δDprecip) from -81.7 to -47 per mil. δDprecip values show a pronounced trend toward heavier compositions during the Miocene (from -80 per mil at 20 Ma to around -45 per mil at 5 Ma), and are markedly heavier than modern isotopic signals derived from westerly moisture sources and influenced by fractionation over the Andes. The Miocene trend toward heavier δDprecip signals contrasts with isotopic predictions due to during Cenozoic global cooling and Andean shortening/topographic relief development during the Miocene, but aligns with trends toward heavier isotopes in reponse to Miocene shifts in climate, the 3-degree northward movement of South America over the same timeframe, and possible dynamic subsidence and marine ingression during development of the middle to late Miocene Paranese Seaway.

New and published geochronology (zircon U-Pb, Ar-Ar) and low-temperature thermochronology (AHe, AFT, and ZHe) analyses, thermal history models, and structural, magmatic, and sedimentological datasets reveal two episodes of shortening-induced uplift and exhumational cooling during construction of the Andean hinterland at ~30 degrees south. The first, at ~40 to 30 Ma, was characterized by ~100 degrees C of rapid cooling (or ~5 to 6 km exhumation) during internal shortening and synorogenic sedimentation in the western Andean hinterland. The second, at ~15 to 5 Ma, involved <60 to 120 degres C of rapid cooling (~2 to 4 km exhumation) along the eastern hinterland flank and was synchronous with 1) the transition from hinterland shortening to strike-slip deformation along the Chile-Argentina border, and 2) slow cooling, erosion, and topographic relief development along the western hinterland domain west of the Punilla-La Plata fault. The spatiotemporal co-occurrence of hinterland thickening, exhumation/cooling, topographic growth, shortening in the external (retroarc) fold-thrust belt, and synorogenic sedimentation after ~16 -15 Ma highlights westward underthrusting of cratonic lithosphere--rather than significant earlier (e.g., Eocene) internal deformation, Miocene or earlier magmatic addition, Miocene-recent lower crustal flow, or deeper processes linked to lithospheric foundering, mantle convection, or subduction dynamics--as the dominant mechanism controlling construction of the thick, elevated hinterland domain.

Finally, this project led to the training and professional development of one female post-doctoral researcher, international field and analytical collaborations among numerous U.S. and Argentine scientists (largely women); and mentorship and research training for Argentine graduate students and six U.S. undergraduate students, four of whom are members of underrepresented groups in the geosciences (Black; women; veteran status; persons with disabilities). The project has supported two publications, one publication in review, one submitted publication, two publications in preparation, an invited conference talk, and other conference presentations.
